awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Emergent Mechanics of Randomly Packed Elastic Filaments
awd_abstract_narration:
When a cardinal builds her iconic cup-nest, she uses her own body as template and molds thin twigs, grass strands, and bark strips into a structure that, despite its softness, reliably holds its shape against various mechanical perturbations. This naturally-selected engineering solution is the result of a subtle interplay between geometry, elasticity, and friction that has not yet been characterized or modeled despite its potential in building, packaging, self-repairing, shock-absorption, and material reusability. The 'bird nest', if defined as a random packing of slender, elastic elements, is an unusual material: it is cohesive without attractive interactions; it is collectively soft and plastic while its elements are hard and elastic.  Through coordinated physical and computational experiments, this collaborative project will advance the science of soft granular materials by relating bulk mechanical properties of idealized 'nest systems' with variations in constituents' properties and geometry. Results will generate new knowledge in granular physics, and will appeal to emerging aleatory architecture and engineering paradigms. Indeed, the ability to build through impermanent contacts and design lightweight materials with prescriptive mechanical properties cuts through many areas of high current importance: civil engineering and architectures (reliable, inexpensive, reusable and self-repairing materials), transportation (lightweight composites, shock absorbers), advanced manufacturing. This is in line with the national need of increasing industry competitiveness, which advances the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secures the national defense. The project also promises to capture the imagination of a broad audience by creating an unusual bridge between relatable protagonists (birds) and often inaccessible fields of physics and engineering. Additionally, STEM outreach activities will be conducted at individual institutions to attract middle school students and female students, respectively, towards science and engineering. Undergraduate students will also be offered positions in either group for exposure to advance engineering research.

With increasing aspect ratio, the mechanical behavior of disordered granular packings changes. Where applied stresses distribute in chains of 1D contacts for spheroids, slenderness introduces bending moments and long-range interaction. Impermanent frictional contacts set the system apart from semi-flexible polymer networks and other non-woven materials which derive mechanical response from permanent crosslinks. Experimental evidence from disordered, randomly packed, elastic fibers or filaments based structures, such as the bird nests, suggest that these material systems exhibit frequency-dependent elastoplastic behavior, finite tensile response, and enhanced specific strength.  In the absence of a theoretical framework and strictly applicable principles of statistical mechanics, an experimental platform for the benchmarking and physical characterization of these materials will be developed in this project.  These will be complemented by a high fidelity computational counterpart to direct a search for novel mechanical states and transitions. The project will provide insights into the relationship between macroscopic and microscopic mechanics of bird nest-like systems, paving the way towards prescriptive design of novel materials.  Moreover, it will spur new directions in granular physics theory and explain a functional mechanism from a naturally-selected engineered structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The project is inspired by the engineering strategy of cup nest building birds, which pack together semiflexible filaments to make multifunctional, cohesive structures with no adhesive material. We are studying simplified, synthetic, nest-like analogs made of straight, flexible rods with table-top experiments and corresponding simulations, specifying constituent element properties and analyzing the geometry and mechanics of the resulting aggregates. We intent to find:

  • Generic relationships between bulk mechanical properties and properties of the constituent elements, such as to facilitate exploration of tunable materials within our simplified parameter space.
  • Micromechanical explanations for phenomena observed in our simplified system which likely apply to other materials composed of and governed by fundamentally similar elements and interactions.
  • Characterization framework amenable to benchmarking computational experiments, such that simulations can be used to further explore experimentally less accessible parts of parameter space for exotic or functional mechanical behavior.
  • Develop high performance framework for undertaking computational experiments, such that nest material design via material parameter optimisation for desired mechanical response can be performed in feasible time.

During this project, we have

  • Validated our direct numerical simulations against quasistatic, oedometric compression experiments with nest- like packings, qualitatively and quantitatively, recovering characteristic macro- and micro-mechanical responses.
  • Employedvalidatedsimulationstoexplainthemicromechanicaloriginsoftheobservednest’snonlinearelasticity and velocity-independent hysteresis. These characteristic features are traced back to the asymmetric shifting of an impermanent network of contact points. These results were featured on the cover of Physical Review Letters and highlighted by focus articles from the American Physical Society and Nature Reviews Physics.
  • Reviewed the state of the field in a perspective article published in Journal of Applied Physics.
  • Developed and continue to maintain and expand the Elastica open software (https://www.cosseratrods.org). Since its launch in April 2020, Elastica’s user community has been growing rapidly, counting 70+ active users (forks) and 20+ known groups (US, UK, Israel, Norway), 250+ clones per week, for a total of 30k+ downloads and hundreds of thousands website views.
  • Developed high performance software (termed Elastica++) for the simulation of systems assembled from tens of thousands to a million Cosserat rods. Elastica++ exhibits 20-100X speedups over the previous solver. Speedups depend on the problem setup. In the case of nest packings, where the main computational detection bottleneck is the rod collision detection algorithm, the speedups are of about 20X. Nonetheless, this improvement still enables us to realise large ‘nests’ with O 104 rods on multi-core shared memory platforms.
  • Performed exploratory investigation into the dynamics of ‘active’ nests (i.e. nests assembled with internally actuated soft filaments) to gain broader understanding relating aggregate response to elemental (individual filament) properties.
  • One graduate student was trained in numerical methods, granular physics, and programming through the course of research in the lab. Another graduate student gained research experience in high performance computing, which was leveraged to develop a high performant version (Elastica++) of the current solver.

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2024
Modified by: Mattia Gazzola

Image

    Copyrighted
    Mattia Gazzola
    'Nest' metamaterials

The project is inspired by the engineering strategy of cup nest building birds, which pack together semiflexible filaments to make multifunctional, cohesive structures with no adhesive material. We are studying simplified, synthetic, nest-like analogs made of straight, flexible rods with table-top experiments and corresponding simulations, specifying constituent element properties and analyzing the geometry and mechanics of the resulting aggregates. Generic relationships between bulk mechanical properties and properties of the constituent elements, such as to facilitate exploration of tunable materials within our simplified parameter space.
Micromechanical explanations for phenomena observed in our simplified system which likely apply to other materials composed of and governed by fundamentally similar elements and interactions.
Characterization framework amenable to benchmarking computational experiments, such that simulations can be used to further explore experimentally less accessible parts of parameter space for exotic or functional mechanical behavior.
Develop high performance framework for undertaking computational experiments, such that nest material design via material parameter optimisation for desired mechanical response can be performed in feasible time.



During this project, we have

Validated our direct numerical simulations against quasistatic, oedometric compression experiments with nest- like packings, qualitatively and quantitatively, recovering characteristic macro- and micro-mechanical responses.
Employedvalidatedsimulationstoexplainthemicromechanicaloriginsoftheobservednestsnonlinearelasticity and velocity-independent hysteresis. These characteristic features are traced back to the asymmetric shifting of an impermanent network of contact points. These results were featured on the cover ofPhysical Review Lettersand highlighted by focus articles from theAmerican Physical SocietyandNature Reviews Physics.
Reviewed the state of the field in a perspective article published inJournal of Applied Physics.
Developed and continue to maintain and expand theElasticaopen software (https://www.cosseratrods.org). Since its launch in April 2020,Elasticas user community has been growing rapidly, counting 70+ active users (forks) and 20+ known groups (US, UK, Israel, Norway), 250+ clones per week, for a total of 30k+ downloads and hundreds of thousands website views.
Developed high performance software (termed Elastica++) for the simulation of systems assembled from tens of thousands to a million Cosserat rods. Elastica++ exhibits 20-100X speedups over the previous solver. Speedups depend on the problem setup. In the case of nest packings, where the main computational detection bottleneck is the rod collision detection algorithm, the speedups are of about 20X. Nonetheless, this improvement still enables us to realise large nests withO104rods on multi-core shared memory platforms.
Performed exploratory investigation into the dynamics of active nests (i.e. nests assembled with internally actuated soft filaments) to gain broader understanding relating aggregate response to elemental (individual filament) properties.
One graduate student was trained in numerical methods, granular physics, and programming through the course of research in the lab. Another graduate student gained research experience in high performance computing, which was leveraged to develop a high performant version (Elastica++) of the current solver.
